explanation: The Fisher scale is useful in communicating the description of SAH. Grade 1: no haemorrhage evident, grade 2: SAH > 1mm, grade 4: associated intra-ventricular haemorrhage or parenchymal extension.
reference: RITI 6b_093 SAH: Acute investigation, treatment and prevention

explanation: This is a spinal dural AV fistula (type 1), the fistula is present within the pial dura, producing distended draining veins on the surface of the spinal cord and oedema secondary to venous hypertension.

Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous is caused by the persistence of the embryonic hyaloid vascular system. Its features are microphthalmia, a vitreous body remnant of the hyaloid artery, retinal detachment and haemorrhage, fluid levels from the degradation of haemorrhage, and calcification.
reference: Aids to Radiological Differential Diagnosis, 4th Ed, p. 387.

explanation: Brain AVMs are the most common symptomatic vascular malformation. They typically present in 20-40 year olds with ictus from haemorrhage, progressive neurological deficit or headaches. Imaging features include: jat CT: serpiginous, densely enhancing vessel without mass effect or oedema; at MR: a nidus of flow voids on T2W sequences, at catheter angiography: grossly dilated vessel resembling a ‘bag of worms’.
reference: Aids to Radiological Differential Diagnosis, 4th Ed, p. 408-410.

explanation: Ref: RITI 6b_008 Plain Skull Radiography.

A number of features are suggestive of nodal metastases: a round, rather than elliptical shape (S/L axis ratio > 0.5), the absence of an echogenic hilum, a cystic area suggestive of necrosis, an ill-defined border, peripheral colour flow with regions of relative avascularity and subcapsular vessels, and punctate calcification (seen in metastases from papillary thyroid carcinoma).
reference: RITI 6a_058 Ultrasound of the Thyroid and Parathyroid Glands.

explanation: This patient suffers from Gorlin-Goltz/basal cell naevus syndrome, associated with multiple cutaneous basal cell carcinomas during childhood, odontogenic keratocysts, ectopic calcifications, and multiple skeletal anomalies. Mental retardation is another recognised association. All of the above answers above can present as cystic lesions of the jaw.
The displacement of the parapharyngeal fascial space can help localize neck lesions: Displacement of parapharyngeal space and styloid musculature.
reference: RITI 6b_053 Imaging Neck Masses, 2nd Ed, p. 698.

explanation: The common craniosynostoses include: Plagiocephaly, Trigonocephaly, Scaphocephaly, Brachycephaly, Oxycephaly, Cloverleaf, Metopic, Sagittal, coronal and lambdoid sutures, as well as multiple paired sutures to produce a 'trilobar' skull.
reference: Radiology Review Manual, 6th Ed, p. 178 & Aids to Radiological Differential Diagnosis, 4th Ed, p. 487.

explanation: Although all the above conditions can result in skull vault lucencies, LCH is the only one that is also associated with surrounding sclerosis. In this case, the sclerotic border indicates the healing phase of LCH. Other conditions that can produce a lucency with sclerosis include: epidermoid, encephalocoele, haemangioma, chronic osteomyelitis, and frontal sinus mucocoele.
reference: Aids to Radiological Differential Diagnosis, 4th Ed, p. 487.

explanation: Schwannomas are the most common CPA mass. The epicentre of the lesion is typically in the epicentre of the internal auditory canal, typically causing a >2 mm difference in canal diameter on the affected side. Extension into the CPA causes an ‘ice cream cone’ appearance. On MR imaging, the lesion is iso-intense on T1W, hyper-intense on T2W and has dense enhancement (however, meningiomas also typically enhance). Calcification is not typical.
reference: Primer of Diagnostic Imaging, 4th Ed, p. 544.

explanation: Chiari | is herniation of the cerebellar tonsils below a line connecting the basion and opisthion. Unlike Chiari Hl, Hl and IV, Chiari | is not associated with myelomeningocoeles. Indeed, the condition is frequently isolated without supratentorial anomalies. As well as the listed associations, Chiari | occurs with: basiliar impression, cranio-vertebral fusion, and Klippel-Feil anomaly.

Although non-specific, enhancement of the intracanalicular and labyrinthine portion occurs in Bell’s palsy (other inflammatory and neoplastic conditions should also be considered). Enhancement of the tympanic and mastoid portions of the facial nerve is a normal variant. Demineralisation does not occur.
reference: Primer of Diagnostic Imaging, 4th Ed, p. 612.
Aids to Radiological Differential Diagnosis, 4th Ed, p. 428.

explanation: MS plaques are typically of high-signal intensity on T2W and Proton density imaging. The hypointense thalamus (and putamen) are due to increased ferritin.

Descending transtentorial (or uncal) herniation is associated with: effacement of the ipsilateral suprasellar cistern, enlargement of the ipsilateral CPA cistern, Duret haemorrhages in the midbrain (which would feature as regions of high attenuation), and PCA ischemia.
reference: Primer of Diagnostic Imaging, 4th Ed, p. 531.

explanation: A number of features are suggestive of a benign, rather than malignant, lesion. Cystic lesions are usually benign; a comet tail artefact usually indicates a (benign) colloid cyst; a complete low- echogenicity ‘halo’ increases the odds of a benign lesion 12 times. The overall echogenicity is another indicator: 96% of hyperechoic lesions are benign, compared to 74% of isoechoic and 39% of hypoechoic lesions.
reference: RIT! 6b_058 Ultrasound of the Thyroid and Parathyroid Glands.

explanation: EpendymomaAstrocytoma AdultChildren More commonLess common TiW signalLowLow/intermediate EnhancementWell defined, strongly defined SyrinxMore commonLess common HaemorrhageMore commonLess common Age Bone remodelling.
reference: RIT! 6b_123 Primary tumours of the spinal cord.

explanation: ‘Red flags’ for potentially serious headache include: precipitation with valsalva manoeuvre, age over 50, new abnormal neurological signs, progressive headache, onset in early morning, associated fever or systemic symptoms, change in character of headache.

Only 1% of meningiomas are associated with internal haemorrhage. Regarding the other characteristics: the inward bulging of the grey-white junction is suggestive of an extra-axial lesion, such as a meningioma; 60% of meningiomas are associated with oedema; meningiomas are typically hyperdense on unenhanced CT imaging and are seen to enhance with i.v. contrast medium.
reference: RITI 6b_116 Characteristic appearances and differential diagnosis of meningiomas.

explanation: Epidermoid tumours are typically iso-intense to CSF on T1 and T2W imaging, with high signal on diffusion weighted sequences and heterogeneous signal on FLAIR imaging. They do not typically enhance.
In older patients with significant atheroma, there is a 1-2% risk of neurological deficit. This is reduced to < 0.5% in younger patients.
reference: RIT! 6b_034 Intra-arterial cerebral angiography: implications, technique and complications.

explanation: Temporo-parietal hypoperfusion is typically caused by Alzheimer’s type dementia or Lewy body disease. Two other patterns to consider include: firstly fronto-temporal hypoperfusion, caused by Pick’s disease, fronto-temporal dementia, chronic alcoholism and schizophrenia; and secondly patchy/ multiple perfusion defects, caused by AIDS-related dementia, schizophrenia and multi-infarct dementia.
The striatum comprises the caudate nucleus and putamen; striatum also includes the globus pallidus.
reference: Primer of Diagnostic Imaging, 4th Ed, p. 500.

explanation: Venous occlusion progresses to infarction in approximately 50% of cases. These infarcts do not conform to arterial territories: occlusion of the midline veins may result in bilateral infarction (low attentation on CT and increased T2W signal on MRI). Acute thrombus is hyperdense on pre-contrast CT imaging; however, i.v. contrast medium results in more intense enhancement of the walls of the sinuses than of their contents (the ‘delta sign’). Haemorrhage is common. Brain swelling is prominent early in the clinical course; this is in contradistinction to arterial infarcts, where swelling is maximal at 3-5 days.
reference: Aids to Radiological Differential Diagnosis, 4th Ed, p. 400.

explanation: On T1W imaging, the anterior pituitary is typically iso-intense and the posterior pituitary hyperintense; on T2W imaging, both the anterior and posterior pituitary are typically iso-intense. The gland is normally flat or concave superiorly, but may be convex in pregnancy.
reference: Primer of Diagnostic Imaging, 4th Ed, p. 580.

explanation: An eccentric enhancing nodule may be seen in cases of toxoplasmosis, but is rare in lymphoma. Callosal involvement, ependymal spread and high attenuation on unenhanced CT imaging are typical features of lymphoma.
reference: Primer of Diagnostic Imaging, 4th Ed, p. 549.

explanation: Orbital pseudotumour tends to: be unilateral (85%), involve the tendons, gland, cause stranding of the lacrimal fat, enlarge, be painful, and have a good response to steroids.
reference: Primer of Diagnostic Imaging, 4th Ed, p. 624.

explanation: A Rathke’s cleft cyst is typically hyperintense on T1W, and has smooth peripheral enhancement with intravenous contrast medium.
A thyroglossal duct cyst is described. Many are infrahyoid (25-60%), the US appearances can be extremely variable.

A craniopharyngioma would typically be seen as a cyst with a mural nodule. Calcification is present in 90% of cases in the younger age group. Both craniopharyngiomas and Rathke cleft cysts have variable signal intensities on MR imaging, but most commonly craniopharyngiomas have a low signal on T1W imaging. The enhancement pattern is typically ‘solid’ or ‘nodular’, as opposed to the ‘rim-like’ pattern seen in Rathke cleft cysts.

A consensus panel has recently defined the US criteria for gauging carotid artery stenosis. Quantitative criteria include: Stenosis Normal<50% ICA PSV (cm/s)< 125 <125 ICA ICA PSV ratio ICA EDV (cm/s) 125-130 > 230 < 2.0 < 40 < 2.0 < 40 undetectable 2.0-4.0 40 - 100 > 4.0 >100 NA NA 50-69% > 70% Total occlusion.

A region that shows both diffusion and perfusion abnormalities represents irreversibly infarcted tissue, while a region that shows only perfusion abnormalities and has normal diffusion represents viable but ischaemic tissue: a ‘penumbra’.

Sturge-Weber syndrome is associated with calcification of the cortical gyri, rather than the basal ganglia. The cause of basal ganglia calcification can be divided into: physiologic, endocrine, (e.g. hypothyroidism, hypoparathyroidism, pseudo- and pseudo-pseudohypoparathyroidism), metabolic (e.g. Fahr’s disease and mitochondrial cytopathies), congenital/ developmental (e.g. Cockayne’s syndrome), infection (e.g. TORCH, cystercercosis, tuberculosis), toxic (e.g. CO poisoning, hypoxia, lead), and chemotherapy/radiotherapy.
reference: Aids to Radiological Differential Diagnosis, 4th Ed, p. 430.

explanation: Time T1WI Signal T2WI Signal 0-12 hours (hyperacute) 12-72 hours (acute) 4—7 days (early subacute) 8-30 days (late subacute) more than 1 month Intermediate Intermediate High High Low High Low Low High Low.
reference: Aids to Radiological Differential Diagnosis, 4th Ed, p. 404.

explanation: Virchow-Robin spaces are invaginations of the sub-arachnoid space into the brain parenchyma. They are seen with increasing frequency with age. The signal intensity is identical to CSF: in the case above, none of the other causes would appear isointense to CSF on FLAIR imaging.
Pycnodyostosis is an autosomal recessive inherited disease featuring dwarfism, learning difficulties, nail dystrophy, receding jaw, wide cranial sutures, and multiple wormian bones.
reference: Aids to Radiological Differential Diagnosis, 4th Ed, p. 486.

explanation: Time T1WI Signal T2WI Signal DWI ADC 0-6 hours Isointense Isointense High Low Low High High Low Low High Low (encephalomalacia) High through T2 shine through.
The ability to cross dural reflections, such as the falx and tentorium cerebelli, places the haematoma in the extra-dural, rather than sub-dural space.
The patient fulfils the diagnostic criteria for Neurofibromatosis type 2. Unlike NF-1, there is no association with Lisch nodules, skeletal dysplasia, optic pathway gliomas or vascular dysplasia.
The commonest ‘soft’ neck masses in infants and children are lipomas, haemangiomas and cystic hygromas. The latter have low-to-intermediate signal intensity on T1W and high signal on T2W.
reference: Aids to Radiological Differential Diagnosis, 4th Ed, p. 394.

explanation: The olfactory (I) and optic (II) nerves are most often affected by base injury.
The typical lesions of diffuse axonal injury are seen more prominently on MR than CT imaging.
The vascular nature of the tumour contraindicates biopsy.

The staging is: T1: tumour confined to vocal cord. T2: supra/ subglottic extension with or without impaired mobility. T3: fixation of true vocal cord. T4: destruction of thyroid cartilage/ extension outside larynx. There is no T5.

The patient has had a transient ischaemic attack (TIA). The Rothwell classification counts a score of 24 counts as a high risk TIA; the risk of a stroke within 4 weeks is up to 20%. 1 point is scored for each of: age (2 60), hypertension (2140/90), diabetes, symptom duration of 40-60 minutes and speech disturbance alone; 2 points for symptoms of >60 minutes or a unilateral weakness. The described patient scores 5 and is therefore high risk, however, recent NICE guidelines state the following management plan for high risk TIAs: 300 mg aspirin should be started immediately, specialist assessment and investigation should be undertaken within 24 hours of onset of symptoms (7 days for low risk patients), and that measures for secondary prevention should be introduced. MR imaging (with DWI) should only be performed if there is uncertainty over the diagnosis or the vascular territory involved. The guidelines also advocate carotid imaging within 7 days with a view to endarterectomy (if appropriate) within 2 weeks.

Oligodendrogliomas are slowly growing gliomas, most commonly located in the frontal lobes. Large nodular calcification is present in approximately 90% of cases. Cystic degeneration, enhancement and a lack of oedema are all common. Over 80% either hypo- or iso-dense on unenhanced CT imaging.
reference: RIT! 6_108 Primary tumours Gliomas — astros, oligos.

explanation: The medial wall of the maxillary sinus is spared in a type II fracture. The pterygoid plates are involved in all Le Fort fractures.
reference: RIT! 6a_024 Trauma of the face, orbit and mandible.

explanation: Longitudinal fractures are parallel to the axis of the petrous pyramid and predominantly affect the middle ear (including the ossicles and tympanic membrane). Transverse fractures are perpendicular to the axis of the petrous pyramid and affect the labyrinth. Facial nerve palsy occurs in 50% of transverse fractures, but only 20% of longitudinal fractures.
In addition, rubella is associated with hearing loss, autism, pigmentary retinopathy, vasculopathy, pulmonic stenosis, and hepatosplenomegaly.

This is the most profound form of holoprosencephaly, where there is almost no separation of the cerebral hemispheres or ventricles. There is a ‘horseshoe’ configuration of neural tissue with a single crescent-shaped ventricle. There is no ‘bilobar’ form of holoprosencephaly. Septo-optic dysplasia can be considered part of the holoprosencephaly spectrum.
This is a leptomeningeal pattern of enhancement. This can be seen in acute stroke, leptomeningeal meningitis, inflammatory diseases such as sarcoid, and metastasis.

Within the first 2 days, enhancement within the pre-operative tumour bed should be regarded as suspicious of incomplete resection. After this time, it is common for enhancing granulation tissue to develop. Dural enhancement is a normal post-operative finding.

DNETs are benign tumours arising from cortical gray matter, most commonly found in the temporal lobes. They are characterised by the presence of multiple cysts and a lack of surrounding oedema. Desmoplastic infantile gangliogliomas typically occur before the 2nd birthday; Oligodendrogliomas typically occur in 30-60 year olds.

Haemorrhagic metastases typically have an incomplete or absent haemosiderin ring. Calcification is rare. Most commonly, there is either nodular, eccentric or ring enhancement. This contrasts with haemorrhagic cerebrovascular malformations, which typically show minimal or central enhancement. Surrounding oedema is present in both the acute/subacute phase.
A mucocoele is the accumulation of mucous secretions behind obstructed bone and sinus cavity ostium. This causes expansion and remodelling. Differentiation from carcinoma can be difficult.
reference: Diagnostic Imaging: Head and Neck, 7th Ed, p. I-2.

explanation: Wernicke’s encephalopathy is associated with necrosis of the mammillary bodies and periventricular demyelination. Marchifava-Bignami disease is associated with hyperintense foci within the corpus callosum on T2W; pontine myelinosis is associated with hyperintense lesions within the pons. Atrophy of the corpus callosum is a recognised feature.
This is a description of coalescent mastoiditis. A Bezold’s abscess represents extension of infection down into the tissues of the neck.
reference: RIT! 6a_017b and glomus tumour. Petrous temporal bone: infection, cholesteatoma.

explanation: Octreotide is a somatostatin analogue, and uptake is seen where somatostatin receptors are expressed, such as neuroendocrine tumours (e.g., glomus tympanicum), and other malignancies (e.g., small cell lung cancer, lymphoma, and breast cancer). There is also uptake in a few tumours that do not express the receptor (e.g., meningioma, astrocytoma).
reference: Nuclear Medicine — The Requisites, 2nd Ed, p. 223-5.

explanation: The mass is most likely a medulloblastoma. These tend to be iso-to-hypo intense on T1W. Leptomeningeal metastases, seen as enhancing nodules, can cause seizures. Hydrocephalus is present in 90% of cases.

Squamous cell carcinoma is usually of heterogeneous, low T2W signal, with a solid enhancement pattern. Bony destruction is seen in approximately 80% of sinonasal SCCs at first presentation. Occupational exposure to nickel, chrome pigment and the use of Bantu snuff are recognised risk factors.

Chordomas originate from the remnants of the embryonic notochord, and may occur at any point along the neural axis. The clivus is the second most frequently affected site. The tumour is locally aggressive, of low T1W signal (giving rise to areas of calcified parenchyma on T1W) and enhances. They are typically isointense to brain parenchyma on T1W.

The 3 main criteria for the definition of a dural tail are: presence on at least two contiguous 5 mm sections through the tumour (although now sections tend to be less than 5 mm thick); the greater thickness being adjacent to the tumour, and enhancement being bedded in association with the tumour itself. Dural tails have classically been described with meningiomas, but can occur with other extra-axial and even intra-axial tumours.

The contents of the jugular foramen include: cranial nerves IX, X, and XI, the inferior petrosal sinus, the internal jugular vein, and the posterior meningeal artery. The middle meningeal artery runs within the foramen spinosum.
The posterior cerebral artery supplies the mesial occipital lobe, and perforators to the thalamus and midbrain.
CNS lymphoma has increased uptake of thallium-201 on SPECT imaging.
Tuberous sclerosis is associated with, amongst other features: cortical tubers, subependymal nodules, giant cell astrocytomas, white matter lesions, retinal phakomas, and vascular abnormalities.
reference: Aids to Radiological Differential Diagnosis, 4th Ed, p. 450.

explanation: The typical attenuation values for commonly encountered tissue types are: bone, 400-1000 HU; congealed blood, 56-76 HU; white matter, 22-32 HU; grey matter, 36-46 HU; water (CSF), 0 HU.
reference: A Textbook of Radiology and Imaging, 5th Ed, p. 1724.

explanation: In the case above, if the ventral subarachnoid space were dilated, this would be more appropriately termed a myelomeningocele. If the dorsal placode were continuous with a lipoma, continuous with the subcutaneous tissues, this would represent a lipomyelocele.
reference: Fundamentals of Diagnostic Radiology, 2nd Ed, p. 312.

explanation: MRA is often used to follow ‘coiled’ aneurysms. Giant aneurysms are rarely visualized to their full extent on 3D time-of-flight MRA because of flow in their nidus. Time-of-flight MRA images may be degraded by the T1-effects of blood degradation products.

Branchial cleft cysts are derived from the 1st or (more commonly) the 2nd cervical pouch. These are usually anterior triangle lesions and of water CT attenuation (< 20 HU). Rim enhancement is seen in infected cysts.

The patient has lower motor neurone signs in the upper limbs and likely upper motor neurone signs in the lower limbs. The most likely diagnosis is a syrinx (syringohydromyelia) within the cervical cord. A Chiari II malformation is usually accompanied by a myelomeningocele, abnormal development of the cerebellar vermis, and hydrocephalus. The herniated cerebellum blocks CSF circulation and leads to the formation of a syrinx within the spinal cord.

The imaging characteristics are those of a choroid plexus papilloma. Meningiomas are rarely intraventricular and most frequently occur in middle-aged women. Colloid cysts occur within the third ventricle. Ependymomas typically arise from the floor of the fourth ventricle.
reference: Clinical Imaging: An Atlas of Differential Diagnosis, 4th Ed, p. 1124.

explanation: The innominate suture is present in all neonates and can be seen posterior to the occipitomental suture. It rarely persists in adulthood.
reference: Accident and Emergency Radiology, 2nd Ed, p. 37.

explanation: A coloboma represents incomplete closure of the foetal choroidal fissure. It can be associated with microphthalmos and is commonly bilateral, where the optic disk is enlarged and elevated.
